awd_titl_txt: Singularities and Black Holes in General Relativity
awd_abstract_narration:
One of the most shocking predictions of general relativity is the existence of black holes; regions of spacetime so dense that nothing, not even light, can escape. In addition to possessing fascinating physical properties, black holes play an essential role in our modern understanding of astrophysics. For example, it is expected that any object undergoing gravitational collapse eventually settles down to a black hole, and also, it is thought that black holes serve to shield us from potentially dangerous gravitational singularities. However, both of these expectations, so fundamental to our view of the universe, lack a definitive mathematical understanding. This project aims to advance our understanding of both the problems of black hole stability and the potential existence of "naked singularities", singular solutions which are not hidden away behind a black hole.

In the last decade there has been a tremendous progress in establishing stability results for model equations on general black hole backgrounds. At the same time, there has been much progress in understanding the true stability problem for the special class of non-rotating black holes. One part of our research plan is to combine these two research directions and to eventually establish a definitive stability theory for rotating black holes. Another part of our research plan is to show that there do in fact exist singular spacetimes which are not hidden behind black holes; however, we will also show that upon a slight perturbation, these particular spacetimes become unstable and develop a black hole.

por.por_cntn:
The theory of General Relativity tells us how spacetime evolves under the influence of gravity. For a long time it has been understood that it is possible for a spacetime evolving according to the rules of General Relativity to break down and experience a singularity. If this happens then, in principle, one must supplant General Relativity with another theory if we want to understand what happens in the actual physical world. It is thus of central importance to understand when and how singularity formation may occur. A central conjecture, called ``weak cosmic censorship," states that generically, when a singularity forms, it is hidden inside of a black hole. These are regions of spacetime which have the strange property that no light or information can escape. Thus, if this conjecture holds, we would be safe from the singularity as long we do physics outside of the black hole (which is generally where we want to be!). While the weak cosmic censorship conjecture has been shown to hold in certain simplified situations, we have a very limited understanding of its potential validity in general.

The first set of projects concern the study of naked singularities for the Einstein vacuum equations. These are spacetimes which have a singularity which is not hidden in a black hole. If weak cosmic censorship holds, then these singularities must be unstable. An important first step to understanding the instability of such strange solutions is to first construct examples of them! In a sequence of two works, one of which was joint with Igor Rodnianski, we constructed the first examples of these naked singularities for the Einstein vacuum equations. These solutions can now provide a testing ground for ideas around the weak cosmic censorship conjecture. One of the key new ideas in our construction is the introduction of a novel type of a self-similar singularity for the Einstein vacuum equations. In a regular spacetime, if you zoom really close to a point, eventually it will look like flat space. However, for a self-similar singularity, when you zoom in on the singular point everything still looks the same, in particular, it does not look like flat space. We introduced a new notion of a twisted self-similar spacetime where when after you zoom in, you also have to "twist" your perspective to see the copy of the spacetime emerge. In a follow-up work I provided a systematic study of this new type of self-similarity.

The second set of projects concerns a problem related to the black hole stability conjecture. This conjecture states that if you slightly perturb a black hole and then let the spacetime evolve according to General Relativity, the resulting spacetime will settle back down to black hole with the energy from the perturbation either falling into the black hole or radiating out to infinity. There has been a tremendous amount of work concerning black hole stability in the last 15 years and lots of progress has been made on various simplified problems. An important preliminary step to black hole stability is to establish linear stability. This concerns the study of a simplified set of equations (the linearized Einstein equations) which one expects to govern the leading order behavior of the perturbation of a black hole. These equations are still extremely complicated. However, there is a special pair of equations, called the Teukolsky equations which are expected to contain the key to the understanding of the whole system. In a pair of joint works with Rita Teixeira da Costa we studied the Teukolsky equations on a black hole spacetime and established that the solutions obey all of the properties that one expects to need in order to go on to establish linear stability and eventually to tackle the full black hole stability problem. Previous work on this problem had always been restricted to either simpler model equations or did not cover the entire family of black holes.
